Nanoconfinement catalysis is becoming a research hotspot in the field of catalytic reactions due to its potential to enhance catalytic performance. Porous nanoconfined catalysts are designed by dispersing nanoparticles of active metal into porous support through various synthesis methods. This kind of catalyst can utilize the confinement effect of the pores to precisely regulate the dispersion and particle size of the metal particles, and then improve their catalytic activity and stability. During the process of catalytic reaction, the confinement effect of the pores in porous materials can effectively optimize the electronic states of the metal active components. Furthermore, the shape-selectivity of the pore channels can significantly improve the selectivity of the reaction products. This paper provides a comprehensive review of recent synthesized strategies for pore-confined metal nano-catalysts and their catalytic applications, and then delves into the mechanism by which the pore-confinement effect enhances catalytic activity, product selectivity, and the stability of catalysts. Specifically, the discussion is focused on various synthesis methods for pore-confined catalysts, including in situ encapsulated, core-shell structured, two-dimensional layered, and single-atom anchored catalysts, as well as recent advances of these catalysts in different catalytic reactions. Finally, the future prospect is proposed in order to provide a guidance for the development and application of pore-confined catalysts in catalytic reaction. Graphical abstract Nanoconfinement catalysis is becoming a research hotspot in the field of catalytic reactions due to its potential to enhance catalytic performance. This paper focuses on the latest research advances of porous nano-confined materials in the field of catalysis. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Nanoconfinement effect Porous material Pore-confined catalysis Structure regulation In situ encapsulated Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Significant distinctions exist in both structure and performance between confined catalysts and traditional catalysts. Conventional catalysts generally feature open active sites that allow unrestricted access to reactants, which commonly results in the decrease of the selectivity and stability. In contrast, confined catalysts achieve precise control for reaction pathways by restricting active metal sites within nanoscale environments, such as pores, cavities, or interlayers [1]. Consequently, confined catalysts demonstrate remarkable advantages in complex reaction systems, and offer new opportunities for efficient and precise catalytic process. In generally, porous nanoconfinement effect mainly comes from the dispersion of metal nanoparticles or clusters into the pores or cavities of porous supports, such as zeolites [2] or carbon nanotubes [3]. In this process, the metal particles interact strongly with the pore surfaces, significantly impacting the activity, adsorption capacity, diffusivity, and stability of the materials [4,5]. As a result, these materials have widely applied in catalysis, hydrogen storage, drug separation, and other fields [6]. Specifically in catalytic reaction, nanoconfined catalysts play a crucial role in regulating the adsorption/desorption states and diffusion properties of various reactants and products through the confinement effect, which effectively enhances the selectivity of the target product. Moreover, the confinement effect facilitates the dispersion and settling of active metal particles on the surface of supports, thereby improving the catalytic efficiency of metal atoms and the anti-sintering and anti-loss ability of the catalysts [7]. So there is an important practical and theoretical significance to deeply investigate the nanoconfinement mechanism of porous catalyst and developing new synthetic method for nanoconfined catalysts. The confinement effect of supported metal catalysts is significantly influenced by the structural and property characteristics of the support materials. Key factors such as pore structure, adsorption capacity, spatial site resistance, and electronic states of the supports play a crucial role in affecting confinement effect at the nanoscale [8–10]. Porous materials are often employed as ideal supports for confined metal catalysts due to their highly ordered pore structure and excellent hydrothermal stability. As presented in Fig. 1 , the pore walls of porous material can generate electronic interactions or interfacial bonding with active metal particles, and then precisely regulate the size and electronic structure of the metal particles. This regulation not only enhances the stability of the active metal on support but also contributes to catalyze specific functional groups, thereby significantly improving the selectivity and stability of the catalysts [11]. For instance, Zhang et al. [12] utilized an isovolumetric impregnation method to load Ni onto mesoporous SBA-15 and prepared the Ni/SBA-15 catalysts. Compared with traditional catalyst with oxide support, the Ni/SBA-15 catalyst shows exceptionally high selectivity for 1,4-butenediol in the selective hydrogenation of 1,4-butynediol. Panpranot et al. [13] employed the incipient wet impregnation method to load Pd onto MCM-41 and SiO2 supports, respectively. In the reaction of hydrogenation of 1-hexene, although both catalysts exhibit similar turnover frequencies (TOF), the Pd/MCM-41 catalyst expresses superior catalytic stability, which can be attributed to the stronger pore confinement effect of the MCM-41 for active metal. In the past, it was a big challenge to prepare truly nanoconfined catalysts with porous structures due to the limitation of traditional loading and doping methods for active metal. There was also a lack of effective means to control the dispersion, placement, and particle size of active metals within the porous support, which greatly limited the application of confined catalysts. Recently, highly dispersed and uniformly sized catalysts with nanoconfinement effect have been developed and prepared successfully thanks to the emergence and application of new methods, such as in situ encapsulation [14] and single-atom anchoring [15] techniques. Yu et al. [16] prepared the in situ encapsulated Rh@S-1 catalyst by confined the active metal Rh in the five-membered ring of an S-1 zeolite. This catalyst demonstrates remarkable aniline selectivity and catalytic stability in the selective hydrogenation of nitroaromatics. Zhang et al. [17] developed a series of single-atom anchoring CoNC catalysts by anchoring single-atom Co in amino-modified carbon nanotubes. These catalysts exhibit outstanding electrocatalytic performance by effectively regulating the electronic state of confinement-activated metals through the formation of Co-N-C covalent bonds. These studies not only demonstrate the potential to enhance the catalytic performance of active metals in porous materials through optimizing the confined structure, but also open new avenues for the preparation of catalysts with nanoconfinement properties. Therefore, the selection of suitable porous materials as the support and the application of the latest synthesis techniques to prepare the catalyst with a new nanoconfined structure have high scientific research value and wide application prospects. It is well known that the traditional metal loading and doping techniques often encounter some practical challenges, such as difficulty in controlling particle size, uneven distribution, and random positioning of active metal. In contrast, nanoconfined metal catalysts offer a perfect solution to deal with these problems by confining active metals to specific regions within porous materials. The confinement effect of the porous support can precisely regulate the particle size and the location of the active metal, and finally significantly enhance the activity, selectivity, and stability of catalysts. This paper is focused on the latest research advances of porous nano-confined materials in the field of catalysis, and emphasizes the structural regulation strategies and the primary construction methods of these catalysts. Moreover, the paper discusses the structural characteristics and application areas of various types of confined catalysts. Finally, the challenges and future development of porous nano-confined catalysts are summarized and prospected. 2 Research progress of porous nanoconfined catalysts with different structures Recently, advances in synthesis technology and characterization methods have enabled the preparation of pore confined catalysts with genuine nanoconfinement effect. By modulating the structure of these catalysts, it has been able to enhance significantly their catalytic performance. The research progress on porous nanoconfined catalysts with different structures is summarized below. 2.1 Research progress of in situ encapsulated porous nanoconfined catalysts Porous materials, such as zeolites [18] and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [19], are highly effective to encapsulate active metal particles in their cages or pores. The confinement effect of in situ encapsulated confined catalysts can be obtained through the formation of chemical bonds between the metal particles and porous wall. Subnanometric metal clusters or metal single-atoms have been encapsulated within porous materials by ligand-stabilized or precursor-stabilized methods during the synthesis process of porous materials, which exhibited superior catalytic activity [16]. This structure promotes the uniform dispersion of metal particles on the support, and then significantly inhibits the aggregation and loss of active metal components, which improves the stability of catalyst. Moreover, in situ encapsulation has normally emerged as a methodology for fabricating porous-confined catalysts, yet the resultant architectures exhibit distinct structural characteristics similarly to other confinement structures. This technique can achieve two different active metal dispersion states along with the preparation of porous-confined catalyst: (i) single-atom sites where metal centers coordinate with oxygen ligands in cavity environments, and (ii) sub-nanometric particles (<2 nm) confined within channels of porous material. Such structure creates unique configurations including localized cationic confinement and physical deposition effects. Here, given these distinctive structure-property relationships, we also classify in situ encapsulation as a confinement architecture category. Till now, several methods are available to synthesize in situ encapsulated porous nanoconfined catalysts, such as hydrothermal synthesis, solvothermal synthesis, and seed-assisted in situ encapsulation. Li et al. [20,21] developed a Pt@Y catalyst by hydrothermally encapsulating Pt in Y zeolite, and the Pt atom is confined in a six-membered ring cage of Y zeolite (Fig. 2 A and B). They found that Pt@Y catalyst was present in Ptδ+···O2− units, which provides a unique environment for H2 activation. This catalyst demonstrated excellent semi-hydrogenation activity and selectivity for unsaturated alcohols in the selective hydrogenation reaction of α, β-unsaturated aldehydes (Fig. 2C). On this basis, a rational mechanism is proposed for the heterolytic cleavage of dihydrogen into H+ and Hδ− and selective reduction of unsaturated aldehydes. Moreover, they also synthesized a Cu@FAU catalyst by encapsulating Cu in a FAU-structured zeolite (Fig. 2D), which achieved a methanol selectivity of 89.5 % in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, outperforming the industrialized Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst. Li et al. [22] successfully synthesized the Pd1@ZSM-5 catalyst using the seed-assisted in situ encapsulation method without templating agents. This method can confine the Pd atoms in the six-membered ring of the ZSM-5 zeolite, which results in a higher TOF of 33,582 molC=C/molPd/h in the semi-hydrogenation of phenylacetylene to styrene compared with all previously reported catalysts. Mechanism studies reveal that Pd1@ZSM-5 features Pd-O-Al/Si bonds, which makes the Pd single-atom with an electron-rich state, thereby promoting the adsorption of substrates on Pd sites and reducing the energy barrier for the semihydrogenation of alkynes. In addition, MOFs also can serve as an excellent support for encapsulated nano-confined catalysts. Yang et al. [23] encapsulated CoP in MOFs to prepare the CoP@quasi-Co-MOF-74 catalyst, which exhibited outstanding catalytic activity in the dehydrogenation process of ammonia-borane, and achieved a hydrogen generation rate of 9,790 mL/min (Fig. 3 A and B). The study reveals that the catalyst features a hierarchical pore structure comprising 1.48 nm micropores and 6.3 nm mesopores, which facilitates the transport and contact between ammonia-borane and the catalyst to accelerate ammonia-borane hydrolysis. Wang et al. [24] prepared an OPH@Zn/Co-ZIF catalyst by confining organophosphorus hydrolase (OPH) in Zn-doping Co-based MOFs using a one-pot method (Fig. 3C). This encapsulated catalyst expressed high activity and stability in the process of organophosphate esters to 4-aminophenol, achieving the complete conversion of 95 μM methyl isothiocyanate to 4-aminophenol in just 15 minutes, with nearly 100 % yield. In summary, in situ encapsulated confined catalysts can modulate the active metals at the atomic-level by the confinement effect of pores, and then prepare successfully the highly dispersed and stable metal nanoparticles or single-atom catalysts. Consequently, these catalysts can exhibit excellent activity, selectivity, and stability in many specific reactions. Although in situ encapsulated method is relatively simple and often requires only one step reaction to obtain metal precursor loaded porous materials, it is difficult for the metal precursors to be completely wrapped in the process of self-assembly of this structure in the solution, which will result in the waste of a large amount of metal precursors. The another problem is that when using this method, it is usually very difficult to accurately control the amount of metal precursor being encapsulated [25]. 2.2 Research progress of core-shell structured porous nanoconfined catalysts Core-shell structured nanoconfined catalysts are composite catalysts composed of metal nanoparticles and shell porous nanomaterials [26]. The synthesis of core-shell nanoconfined catalysts typically involves a two-step process. Initially, stable metal nanoparticles are prepared, often utilizing stabilizing agents such as polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) or cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) to control particle size and prevent aggregation. Subsequently, a porous shell is constructed on the surface of the nanoparticles using strategies such as seed-assisted growth or layer-by-layer deposition. For core-shell nanoconfined catalysts, the active metal particles as a core are confined within the interior of porous shells. Not only does the shape-selectivity of the porous shell significantly enhance the selectivity of the target product, but the confinement effect of the nano-shell also notably improves the stability of the catalyst [27]. Xiao et al. [28] successfully prepared a kind of Pd@S-1 zeolite catalyst with a core-shell structure using solvent-free method (Fig. 4 A). This catalyst demonstrated superior catalytic activity and furan selectivity in the furfural hydrogenation reaction compared with the Pd/S-1 catalyst prepared by traditional methods. The density functional theory (DFT) calculations in the case show that the adsorption energy of furan in the Pd@S-1 catalyst is significantly lower than that of other molecules, indicating that furan has the fastest diffusion rate in the micropores of S-1 supports. Therefore, the catalyst exhibits excellent furan selectivity in the furfural hydrogenation reaction. Xu et al. [29] synthesized CdS@ZIF-8 photocatalysts using a two-step method, which involved the growth of a ZIF-8 MOFs on CdS nanoparticles (Fig. 4B). These photocatalysts exhibited excellent catalytic activity and selectivity in the photocatalytic reaction for formic acid to hydrogen, and the by-product CO generation amount is only 3.2 %, which is far lower than that of CdS nanoparticles (12.5 %). Ma et al. [30] successfully developed the Fe3O4@ZSM-5 zeolite catalyst with core-shell structure by encapsulating Fe3O4 colloidal cores in ZSM-5 zeolite with a stepwise crystallization method (Fig. 4C). This catalyst achieved the 95 % conversion of ethanol and the 98 % selectivity of ethylene in ethanol dehydration reactions. Tang et al. [31] prepared a Au/Snβ@mesosilica bifunctional catalyst using the deposition precipitation method, where mesoporous SiO2 covered the surface of microporous Snβ zeolites, and Sn-anchored Au nanoparticles were confined within the β zeolite pores. The catalyst showed higher conversion of glycerol (98.2 %) and the selectivity of lactic acid methyl ester (91.9 %) in glycerol reforming reactions, outperforming the Au/Snβ catalyst prepared by conventional methods. Liu et al. [32] synthesized a kind of PdCu@SiO2@Cu catalyst with a novel core-shell structure by the reverse microemulsion method. Here, beyond the conventional synthesis of metal nanoparticles and layer-by-layer deposition, a silylation reagent is employed to graft the reactive -NH2 group to the surface of the SiO2 shell. These grafted groups serve as anchoring sites to capture metal cations, facilitating the formation of satellite particles (Fig. 4D). The catalyst showed an ethylene selectivity of 89 % in acetylene selective hydrogenation reactions. In conclusion, core-shell structured confined catalysts effectively confine active metals in the porous shell layer, which not only optimize the interaction between reactant and active site, but also promote the generation of target product. In the meantime, the protective effect of the shell material for the active metal can effectively shield the contamination by the external environment, thus greatly improving the stability of the catalyst. In addition, although the porous shell architecture effectively disperses and stabilizes metallic nanoparticles, this protective configuration concomitantly reduces catalytic activity through restricted mass transport and diminished accessibility to active sites [33]. 2.3 Research progress of two-dimensional layered porous nanoconfined catalysts Two-dimensional layered nanoconfined catalysts are synthesized by confining active metals within the interfaces of layered materials, such as graphene and MoS2 [34]. The synthesis of two-dimensional layered materials can be broadly categorized into two primary strategies: top-down and bottom-up approaches. The top-down method involves the exfoliation or etching of bulk precursors to yield thin layers. For instance, mechanical exfoliation, liquid-phase exfoliation, or chemical etching are commonly employed. Wu et al. [35] prepared two-dimensional HOF ultrathin nanosheets via ultrasonic exfoliation and adaptively embedded nanoparticles by exploiting the reversibility of hydrogen bonds. Huang et al. [36] developed a Lewis acidic etching strategy, which selectively removed the Al layer from the MAX phase by metal cations in high-temperature molten salts to prepare MXene material. In contrast, the bottom-up approach relies on the controlled growth of two-dimensional materials from atomic or molecular precursors. A prominent example is chemical vapor deposition (CVD), which enables the synthesis of large-area, high-crystallinity two-dimensional layers, such as graphene, transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs), and hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) [34,37]. Subsequently, a post-treatment approach is employed to confine the active metal species within the interlayers of the two-dimensional material, resulting in the synthesis of two-dimensional layered nanoconfined catalysts. The stronger chemical bond between the interfacial layer and the active metal particles can regulate the electronic state of metal atoms, and produce an unsaturated metastable structure of active atoms, which is helpful to improve the catalytic activity of the catalyst [38,39]. Zhang et al. [40] prepared the NiFe-MOFs//G electrocatalyst by confining MOFs within the graphene interface. This catalyst demonstrated exceptional catalytic activity and stability in the oxygen evolution by electrolysis of water, achieving an overpotential of only 106 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 and stable operation for over 150 hours (Fig. 5 A). According to the mechanism research, they discovered that the nanoconfinement effect from graphene multilayers induces the formation of highly reactive NiO6-FeO5 distorted octahedral species in MOF structure, which significantly enhance the efficiency of the catalytic reaction. Huo et al. [41] employed the impregnation-vacuum diffusion method to synthesize Mo2N/SBA-15/rGO catalysts, where Mo2N nano-single crystals were confined within the two-dimensional space of a zeolite/graphene composite. The as-synthesized catalysts possess large specific surface area (185 m2/g) and well-organized mesopores (3.7 nm). Meanwhile, the confinement effect significantly improved the dispersion and stability of Mo2N in the zeolite/graphene composite, resulting in a hydrogen production rate of 30.58 mmol·g−1·min−1 during the ammonia decomposition reaction. Jiang et al. [42] utilized laser molecular beam epitaxy technique to confine single atoms of Ni and Fe within nanolayer of MoS2, bending the layered MoS2 to create NiFe@MoS2 catalysts. These catalysts exhibited outstanding catalytic activity and selectivity in acidic water splitting, with an overpotential of only 67 mV at the same current density, significantly lower than that of the commercial IrO2 catalyst (338 mV). Ge et al. [43] synthesized successfully metal hydroxide organic frameworks catalysts with a two-dimensional confinement structure (2D d-MHOFs) using hydrotalcite as a precursor (Fig. 5B). The ordered and stable structure was achieved by incorporating Fe, Co and Ni species in a specific sequence, resulting in an overpotential of only 207 mV in the hydrogen evolution reaction of electrolyzed water, which is considerably lower than that of traditional catalysts. In conclusion, two-dimensional layered confinement catalysts can effectively suppress metal migration and aggregation through interlayer van der Waals interaction. However, the restricted interlayer spacing typically limits their catalytic applications for small-molecule transformations. 2.4 Research progress of single-atom anchored porous nanoconfined catalysts The concept of single-atom catalysis was first proposed by the team of Academician Tao Zhang of Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics. CAS in 2011, and has quickly become the research front in the field of catalysis [44]. Over the past decade, numerous strategies for anchoring single atoms have been explored, including crystal plane control [45], interface engineering [46], strain engineering [47], and defect engineering [48]. Among these strategies, defect engineering has emerged as a particularly promising approach due to its high density of anchoring sites, local chemical environments, and simple synthesis methods. These advantages have made defect engineering widely applied in the preparation of single-atom catalysts supported by porous materials. For single-atom anchored porous nanoconfined catalysts, active metal atoms are anchored to defect sites of porous support materials by the formation of covalent bonds, and the strong metal-support interaction makes the single atom confined catalyst show excellent catalytic performance [49–51]. Zhang et al. [52] prepared a Co-N-C single-atom catalyst by one-pot roasting method, and the Co atom was anchored at the defect site of mesoporous carbon nitride material. The catalyst expressed higher catalytic activity and stability in the hydrogenation of nitroaromatics to azo compounds. Lu et al. [53] used atomic layer deposition technique to anchor single-atom Cu on the graphitic carbon nitride support at first, and further anchor Ni atoms on the support by the formation of hydroxylated Cu, successfully preparing the Ni1Cu2/g-C3N4 catalyst with a three-atom cooperative catalytic structure. The conversion of this catalyst was higher 11 times than that of the traditional Ni1/g-C3N4 catalyst in the selective hydrogenation of acetylene, along with higher ethylene selectivity and catalytic stability. The mechanism study reveals that the Ni site dynamically changes by breaking the chemical bonds of Ni-support during reactant adsorption and forming these bonds on product desorption (Fig. 6 A and B). In additional, single atom catalysts with high loading amount are also an important development direction in the field of single atom catalysis [54–56]. Hai et al. [57] prepared the UHD Ni1/NC single-atom catalyst by two-step annealing method, where Ni atoms were selectively anchored at the N4 defect site of the support by annealing treatment, and the loading amount of the metal was high up to 16.3wt %. Comprehensive characterization and theoretical calculations reveal that the Ni precursor migrates to the defect sites of the nitrogen carbide material in the first annealing. Further annealing removes the remaining ligands, enabling the successful anchoring of Ni atoms at the N4 sites of the nitrogen carbide. The catalyst showed excellent catalytic activity and stability in the carbon dioxide reduction reaction, which was significantly better than the Ni1/NC catalyst with low loading. Wang et al. [58] developed the Pt SACs/PCN catalyst by negative pressure annealing method, and the active metal particles were anchored on the nitrogen carbide support as single atom. The conversion rate of the catalyst was up to 71.9 mmol/gcat in the propane oxidation reaction (Fig. 6C and D). In short, porous materials, due to their large specific surface area and abundant anchoring sites, provide an ideal space and microenvironment for the loading of metal single atoms. Furthermore, through the specific post-treatment process for the catalyst, the loading capacity of the single atom catalyst can be significantly increased to meet the needs of industrial production. It is noteworthy that both in situ encapsulation technique and single-atom anchoring strategies can be employed to fabricate single-atom confined catalysts supported by porous materials. However, these methods differ significantly in their mechanisms and outcomes. In situ encapsulation technique primarily relies on spatial confinement and electrostatic interactions in the pores or cages of the material to confine metal complexes, followed by removal of ligand to yield single-atom catalysts. This approach typically results in structures with exceptional stability but relatively low catalytic activity. In contrast, single-atom anchoring catalyst utilizes defect sites of the porous material to immobilize and bond with single metal atoms. The density of defect site directly influences the metal loading, which makes it possible to achieve single-atom catalysts with high metal loading and catalytic activity. By the end of this paragraph, we summarize the properties and synthesized methods of the porous nanoconfined catalysts with different structures as shown in Table 1 . 3 Application advances of porous nanoconfined catalysts Porous nanoconfined catalysts have expressed exceptional catalytic performance in selective hydrogenation, dehydrogenation, and isomerization reaction, and so on. Their unique structures can precisely control the molecular diffusion pathway and intermediate stabilization. This structural advantage significantly enhances product selectivity of reaction, and effectively restrains the catalyst deactivation through spatial restriction for metal sintering [59]. Here, we illustrate in detail the application advances of porous nanoconfined catalysts to deeply understand the advantages and generality of porous confined catalysis in some important chemical reactions, including syngas to olefin, dehydrogenation of n-alkanes, and synthesis of fine chemicals. 3.1 Application of porous nanoconfined catalysts in syngas to olefin reactions Syngas to olefin reaction is an important catalytic process in energy industry, which transforms the syngas (CO/H2) derived from coal, natural gas or biomass into light olefins (C2-C4) and chemicals. This technology not only enhances the high-value utilization of coal resources, but also reduces the dependence on conventional petroleum-based route. However, the intrinsic challenge of competitive C-C coupling reaction and the requisite high temperature inevitably leads to unsatisfactory catalytic performance, expressing as poor product selectivity and catalyst stability [60]. According to the previous research works, the porous nanoconfined metal catalysts play a crucial role in syngas to olefin reactions. The shape selectivity of nanopores can change the diffusion pathways of reaction intermediates in syngas-to-olefin reaction, selectively allowing molecules with suitable sizes (e.g., ethylene, propylene) to pass, thereby significantly enhancing the selectivity of target product. Furthermore, compared to traditional open catalytic systems, the nanoconfinement effect markedly improves the stability and anti-sintering capability of confined catalysts. This is attributed to the confined mobility of active metals within the nanopores, which prevents aggregation and deactivation under harsh reaction conditions [61,62]. Hu et al. [63] developed a Fe@n-hS-HT catalyst with a core-shell structure using melt recrystallization technique, and the Fe species were encapsulated in the cavities of hollow S-1 zeolite, which effectively prevented the loss of active components. This catalyst exhibited significantly higher activity and light olefin selectivity in the syngas to olefin reaction compared with the Fe/S-1 catalyst synthesized by the conventional impregnation method. Xu et al. [64] encapsulated Fe and Mn active metal species with porous SiO2 as the shell layer, and then prepared the FeMn@Si catalyst with excellent hydrophobicity by the hydrophobic modification for surface (Fig. 7 A). In the process of syngas to olefins, the porous hydrophobic shell of this catalyst significantly suppressed the side reaction of water-gas shift and prevented the oxidation of the active component of iron carbide, demonstrating higher CO conversion rate with 56.1 % and light olefin selectivity with 83.3 % than traditional non-porous ε-Fe2C catalysts. In addition, the application of metal oxide-zeolite bifunctional catalysts in the process of the syngas to light olefin has also drawn a widespread attention. Bao et al. [65] combined the spinel structure ZnCrOx with SAPO-34 zeolites to successfully prepare a ZnCrOx/SAPO bifunctional catalyst. This catalyst achieved a CO conversion rate of 17 % and a selectivity for light olefin of 80 % in the direct conversion of syngas to light olefin. Mechanism studies reveal that CO is activated on the surface of ZnCrOx at first, and then diffuse into the zeolite pores where it participates in coupling reactions to generate light olefins. On this basis, Wang et al. [66] employed a sequential template method to develop a ZnCrOx/SAPO bifunctional catalyst with a hollow multi-shell structure, which achieved a remarkable light olefin selectivity of up to 90 % in the syngas to olefin reaction (Fig. 7B). Subsequently, Bao et al. [67] prepared the GeAlPO-18 molecular sieve catalysts with metal Ge ion isomorphous substitution by hydrothermal synthesis method, and the catalyst demonstrated extremely high catalytic activity in the syngas to olefin reaction. Both the CO conversion rate and the selectivity for light olefin exceeded 80 %, which was higher than that of all previously reported catalysts. Characterization and theoretical calculations demonstrate that the active sites of Brønsted acid improve the conversion rate of ketene intermediates to olefins as well as inhibit the secondary reactions of hydrogenation and oligomerization of olefin (Fig. 7C). 3.2 Application of porous nanoconfined catalysts in dehydrogenation of n-alkanes reactions The dehydrogenation of n-alkanes to olefin plays an important role in reducing petroleum energy consumption and solving the problem of olefin supply and demand. But dehydrogenation of n-alkanes is easily overoxidized to form valueless CO2, which limits its practical application. The nanoconfinement effect effectively stabilizes key reaction intermediates (e.g., alkyl radicals) generated during the catalytic process, thereby suppressing their decomposition and undesired side reactions, which consequently enhances the selectivity toward alkene [68]. Xiao et al. [69] constructed isolated B centers in pure silica MFI zeolites, and successfully synthesized a BS-1 catalyst by solvent-free method. The catalyst not only effectively activates molecular oxygen and propane to promote dehydrogenation, but also significantly reduces the energy barrier for C3H7 intermediate formation. (Fig. 8 A). The catalytic activity and stability are far superior to the traditional non-porous supported boron oxide catalytic materials, and the selectivity of propylene is more than 80 %. Lu et al. [70] successfully synthesized a BZEO-2 catalyst by doping the active component B in ZEO-2 zeolite with a MWW structure (Fig. 8B), and this catalyst has a high propylene selectivity up to 83.6 % in the dehydrogenation of propane. Farzaneh et al. [71] confined VOX within the UiO-66 metal organic framework (MOFs) using one-pot method, and successfully synthesized the V/UiO-66 catalyst (Fig. 8C). The abundant organic ligands of this catalyst not only stabilize the V species but also effectively prevent the direct contact between reactants and metal oxides, which results in the higher catalytic activity and propylene selectivity than VOX/γ-Al2O3 in the propane dehydrogenation reaction. Liu et al. [72] prepared the NiSn@S-1 bimetallic catalyst via a one-step hydrothermal synthesis method and the catalyst exhibits excellent catalytic activity and selectivity for the target product in the propane dehydrogenation reaction, with a propylene selectivity of over 88 % (Fig. 8D). The study reveals that the confined microenvironment effectively stabilizes both the 2-propyl intermediate and NiSn subnanoclusters. Zhou et al. [73] prepared a kind of Ru1/NC single-atom catalyst by anchoring Ru to carbon nitride materials with the ball milling method (Fig. 8E). In the process of propane dehydrogenation, the catalyst displayed exceptional catalytic performance and stability, reaching a high propylene selectivity of 92 %. There is no doubt that the porous nanoconfined catalyst demonstrates an excellent selectivity of propylene and catalytic stability in the dehydrogenation reaction of propane. However, significant challenges also persist in achieving great improvement for catalytic activity. 3.3 Application of porous nanoconfined catalysts in synthesis of fine chemicals Generally speaking, the structure of the synthetic raw materials for high-value fine chemicals is relatively complex, there may be two or more functional groups such as CC, C=C, C=O, so the choice of catalyst in the reaction becomes the key factor for synthesis of fine chemicals [74]. The porous nanoconfined catalysts express exceptional selectivity in fine chemical synthesis because of its tailored metal coordination environment that can precisely activate specific functional groups as well as suppress competing reaction pathways [75]. Li et al. [76] prepared an in situ encapsulated Pd@MFI catalyst using microporous zeolite with MFI structure as support, which obtained furan, furfuryl alcohol and 1,5-pentanediol products with correspondingly high selectivity according to the different supports (silicalite-1, Na-ZSM-5 and H-ZSM-5, respectively) in the selective hydrogenation reaction of furfural. Chen et al. [77] developed a Pt@HA catalyst by sol-gel method, and the active metal Pt atoms are confined in the frame of zeolite, which can avoid the direct interaction between the furfural and the active metal. The catalyst exhibited excellent activity and selectivity of furfuryl alcohol (approaching 100 %) in the hydrogenation of furfural, since the reaction was efficiently catalyzed by hydrogen spillover (Fig. 9 A). An in situ encapsulated Pt@ZSM-48 catalyst using a one-pot method was synthesized by Zhang et al. [78]. The catalyst demonstrated high catalytic activity and 1,4-butynediol (BED) selectivity in the hydrogenation of 1,4-butynediol (BYD) (Fig. 9B). The DFT calculations demonstrate that the ZSM-48 channels exhibit strong adsorption ability toward BYD and the weaker adsorption for BED, which facilitates the faster diffusion of BED through the zeolite pores. In addition, the narrow pores (∼0.6nm) of ZSM-48 inhibit the process of BYD isomerization, thus exhibiting higher BED selectivity than that of non-porous materials. Jia et al. [79] applied a host-guest synthesis strategy to confined Co precursors in MOFs, and successfully synthesized the Co/ZIF-1000 monoatomic catalyst after high temperature calcination. The catalyst achieved a 99.9 % conversion of styrene and 71 % selectivity of phenylene oxide ethane in the styrene epoxidation reaction, which was significantly superior to the non-porous Co2O3 catalyst. The confined Co-N3 structure significantly reduces the energy barrier for the conversion of transition state 4 (TS4) to styrene oxide, thus enhancing the catalyst's selectivity (Fig. 9C). Yang et al. [80] prepared a Ru/β monoatomic catalyst by initial wet impregnation method, in which Ru atoms were anchored on the Lewis acidic sites of the β zeolite and uniformly dispersed on the support (Fig. 9D). The catalyst showed high catalytic activity and 93 % selectivity for epoxidation of styrene. In conclusion, porous nanoconfined catalysts can achieve high selectivity and stability in the synthesis of high-value fine chemicals by regulating the distribution and location of active metal sites. Further exploration of porous confined catalysts in fine chemical synthesis should be actively pursued. 3.4 Application of porous nanoconfined catalysts in other reactions Besides the above mentioned reactions, nanoconfined catalysts also demonstrate exceptional catalytic performance in other reaction processes, such as CO2 hydrogenation, hydroisomerization of n-alkane and so on. The nanoscale channels of these catalysts precisely control the formation of intermediates and products in these hydrogenation reactions by their unique spatial confinement effects. Liu et al. [81] successfully designed a Mo3S4@NaZSM-5 catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol by confining Mo3S4 clusters in 10-membered rings (10-MR) of NaZSM-5 zeolite through a mechanical mixing and calcination method (Fig. 10 A). Based on the DFT calculations and operando FT-IR spectra results, they find that CO2 convert to methanol by various intermediates like *CO, *CHO, *CH2O, and *CH3O in the confined catalytic system (Fig. 10B). Zeng et al. [82] synthesized a core-shell structured Cu/MoS2@SiO2 catalyst by uniformly depositing a silica shell on the surface of MoS2 nanoparticles and anchoring Cu at MoS2 (Fig. 10C and D). This catalyst showed excellent performance in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, achieving a methanol selectivity of 72 % and a CO2 conversion rate of 12 %, significantly superior the commercial Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst. In addition, Lv et al. [7] synthesized a Ni/SAPO-11 catalyst with one-pot method, in which the active Ni species were confined in the zeolite framework. Compared to the catalyst prepared by conventional impregnation method, this catalyst exhibited superior catalytic performance in n-hexane hydroisomerization, achieving a high n-hexane conversion rate of 71.2 % and an isohexane selectivity of 66.7 % (Fig. 11 A). Zhang et al. [83] obtained a Pt/HL catalyst by in-situ encapsulation technique, which confined Pt nanoparticles within the 12-MR of HL. In the hydroisomerization process of n-hexane, the catalyst demonstrated a high conversion rate of n-hexane (61.4 %) and an exceptional selectivity of isomer (96.7 %) (Fig. 11B). Wang et al. [84] successfully prepared Pd-SnOx@MFI catalysts with an ethylenediamine-assisted encapsulation strategy that confined Pd and Sn nanoparticles within MFI zeolite frameworks. This catalyst exhibited superior performance in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen, steadily outperforming the catalysts tested previously. The catalytic performances of porous nanoconfined catalysts in different reactions are partly listed in Table 2 . 4 Conclusion and prospects As an important branch of modern catalysis science, confined catalysis not only enhances the stability of the active component and optimizes its electronic structure through the exquisitely designed nano-space to confine the active component, but also promotes the formation of reaction intermediates and the diffusion of products in the catalytic process, thus achieving synchronous improvement of catalytic activity, selectivity and stability. Porous materials are often selected as an ideal support for confined catalysts due to their highly ordered pore structure and excellent hydrothermal stability. When active metal particles are loaded on these porous materials, the pore wall of the porous material can produce electronic interaction or interface bonding with the active metal particles, which enhances the stability of the metal particles and the selective catalytic ability for specific functional groups, thus significantly improving the selectivity and stability of the catalyst. This review systematically summarizes several innovative strategies for improving active metal dispersion and stability by utilizing the unique confinement effect of porous materials in the design of metal catalysts. Meanwhile, this article also conducts an in-depth analysis of the latest advances for these confined catalysts in various application fields, and provides a comprehensive summary and review. After winning the 2024 Future Science Award, Prof. Yadong Li predicted that single-atom catalysts would be industrialized on a large scale within two or three years. However, the low metal loading amount of single-atom catalysts significantly limits their potential for industrial application. Therefore, increasing the metal loading of single-atom catalysts, developing new catalytic reactions, advancing advanced characterization techniques, and deepening the theoretical understanding of single-atom catalysis have become the key factors to overcoming the industrialization challenges of single-atom catalysts. The regular pore structure and numerous anchoring sites of porous confined metal catalysts have become a key strategy for synthesizing high-loading single-atom catalysts. Future research on porous nano-confined catalysts may focus on three main aspects: i) to precisely control the size, shape, and distribution of the pores in porous nanomaterials, so as to maximize mass transfer efficiency and the accessibility of catalytic active sites; ii) to understand the confinement effect of the catalyst on reaction pathways, interface structures and catalytic performance, and to study the mechanism of confined catalysis by using the latest in situ characterization technology; iii) to resolve the issue of large-scale preparation of porous nanoconfined catalysts, and to facilitate the practical application of the catalysts in energy conversion, environmental governance and other fields. In summary, future research on porous nanoconfined catalysts will focus on precise control, performance optimization, and large-scale production. This development trend indicates that the catalysis field is on the verge of ushering in a new round of technological innovation and industrial upgrading. coredata.dc:description: Nanoconfinement catalysis is becoming a research hotspot in the field of catalytic reactions due to its potential to enhance catalytic performance. Porous nanoconfined catalysts are designed by dispersing nanoparticles of active metal into porous support through various synthesis methods. This kind of catalyst can utilize the confinement effect of the pores to precisely regulate the dispersion and particle size of the metal particles, and then improve their catalytic activity and stability. During the process of catalytic reaction, the confinement effect of the pores in porous materials can effectively optimize the electronic states of the metal active components. Furthermore, the shape-selectivity of the pore channels can significantly improve the selectivity of the reaction products. This paper provides a comprehensive review of recent synthesized strategies for pore-confined metal nano-catalysts and their catalytic applications, and then delves into the mechanism by which the pore-confinement effect enhances catalytic activity, product selectivity, and the stability of catalysts. Specifically, the discussion is focused on various synthesis methods for pore-confined catalysts, including in situ encapsulated, core-shell structured, two-dimensional layered, and single-atom anchored catalysts, as well as recent advances of these catalysts in different catalytic reactions. Finally, the future prospect is proposed in order to provide a guidance for the development and application of pore-confined catalysts in catalytic reaction.
